Dialogue.NPCText:
Ejan stands by the sacred fire, his body painted with swirling ochre and white. He lifts his head to the sky and howls—a deep, mournful sound that stirs the air and sends birds scattering.

He lowers his mask and fixes you with amber eyes.
“Awooo... You walk in the shadow of the groves, outsider. The spirits are restless. Will you listen to their warnings, or wander lost in the darkness?”

Option.text: I will listen. What troubles the spirits?
Who are you to speak for spirits?
That was some howl! Teach me your ways?
Tell me more about yourself, Stonehowl.
I mean no harm. Just passing through.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Ejan’s eyes narrow as he grips his wildstaff.
“Awooo... Last moon, I called for the White Hart. But the veil was thin—something foul answered instead. A shadow in the form of a beast stalks our woods, its hunger unnatural. It spreads Minax’s corruption to the animals who drink from the moonlit pool.

Will you aid the Verdant, and cleanse what I have summoned by mistake?”

Option.text: Tell me what must be done.
What sort of beast is it?
What happens if we do nothing?
This sounds dangerous. I must decline.

Dialogue.NPCText:
“Good. Awooo... You must find the tainted pool north of our groves. There you’ll face the Shadow-Beast. Burn its essence with this Spiritfire Totem and bring me its Blackened Fang.

But beware—only those strong in Spirit or Nature magics can withstand its howl. If you are neither, find an ally or accept the forest’s trial.”

Option.text: I am ready. Give me the Spiritfire Totem.
Is there another way to defeat it?
What if I fall to its howl?
I will return when I am prepared.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Ejan hands you a totem wreathed in living vines and faintly glowing embers.
“The Spiritfire Totem burns with the breath of the ancestors. Use it at the pool to weaken the beast’s corruption, then strike swiftly.

Return with its Blackened Fang as proof—and the spirits may forgive my folly.”

Ejan inclines his head.
“You still carry the Spiritfire Totem. Find the shadow-beast and burn its corruption, then bring me its fang.”

Option.text: Remind me—what should I do again?

Dialogue.NPCText: “Awooo... If you lack spirit or druidic power, perhaps the elders of the Verdant or the monks of Hinokami may help. Some brew potions against fear, others bind courage in song. But alone, you must trust your strength—or be wise enough to seek allies.”

Option.text: Thank you. I will seek help if needed.

Dialogue.NPCText:
“The beast’s howl can freeze the blood of the bravest. If you fall, the spirits will guide your soul back—once. After that, not even I can call you from the darkness.
Be prepared, or bring friends you trust.”

“The shadow-beast wears many forms—a wolf, a stag, sometimes a twisted bear. Its eyes burn violet, and it leaks black mist. It feasts on fear and corrupts all it wounds. Even our bravest hunters will not track it now.
Only fire and courage may unmake it.”

“If nothing is done, the beast’s curse will spread. Wolves, birds, even the trees will turn mad, and the Verdant Tribes will be forced to abandon the groves.
This is the work of Minax—a shadow on all living things. We must not let it take root.”

“Awooo... I am Ejan, called Stonehowl—beast-caller, priest of the Verdant, keeper of the sacred howl.
My ancestors were wolves and trees before they were men. I serve the council, the spirits, and the wild—sometimes well, sometimes not, it seems.”

“Awooo! The howl is more than sound—it is prayer, challenge, memory. We howl to call the ancestors, to warn of danger, to mourn, and to rejoice.
Perhaps you would learn? First, stand tall. Let your breath reach the roots of your belly. Feel the pulse of the earth, then send your voice into the sky!”

Ejan demonstrates, and even the trees seem to listen.
“When you are ready, howl with me at the next moonrise. If the spirits smile, you may earn their blessing.”

Ejan nods, approvingly.
“You carry the howl of the wild now—walk with strength. May the spirits watch your steps.”
(You feel invigorated.)

Ejan closes his eyes, listening to the forest.
“Then walk softly. Even in peace, the spirits watch and weigh all trespass.”

Option.text: Wait, I have questions for you.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Ejan’s face lights with relief as he takes the Blackened Fang.
“Awooo... You have done what I could not. The spirits sing your name tonight, outsider.
Accept this boon—a gift of the wild, and the Verdant’s thanks.”
“The groves are safer, for now. If you ever wish to join the Verdant in ritual or in hunt, you will be welcomed. Awooo!”

Ejan breathes deeply, lowering his staff.

“Awooo... The spirits teach us not to dwell in the past, but you have asked, and the wind carries no falsehood. I was born beneath the Shadowroot Tree, third son of Vaka the Hollow-Voiced. I did not cry at birth. They feared I had no soul.”

“But in dreams, I howled—and the wolves answered.”

Option.text: Why do you howl like that?
Do you believe the spirits truly guide us?
I’ve heard whispers you were once exiled...

Dialogue.NPCText:
“Awooo! The howl is not just noise—it is *resonance*. It aligns the body with spirit, tree, wind, and beast. Even Minax fears what the wild remembers. I howl to call my ancestors, to soothe wounded roots, to remind myself who I was... and who I am still.”

“Try it sometime. A deep howl can shake your bones loose of sorrow.”

Option.text: Could you teach me to howl?
Tell me more of your past.

Dialogue.NPCText:
“I ran with foxes before I walked upright. My brothers were hunters; I was the odd one who fed moths and stared at bark. My tribe feared I would speak to stones before I ever spoke to men.”

“One day, I vanished into the woods for a fortnight. When I returned, my voice was no longer my own—it was theirs.”
(He taps his chest, then the air.)

“My mother wept with pride... and fear. My brothers did not understand. One tried to silence my voice with his fists.”
(Ejan gestures to a scar on his brow.)

“I do not blame him. The howl calls both harmony and madness. Those who walk with spirits must be ready to walk alone.”

Option.text: Is that why you became a priest?

Dialogue.NPCText:
(Ejan lowers his head, voice quieter.)
“Thank you. Few speak with such warmth in these times. Awooo... May your kindness echo through the glades.”
(You feel a subtle warmth surround you.)

“Loneliness? No. I was among birds, roots, ancestors. Loneliness only returns when I enter crowds and hear no songs.”
“I would rather dine with wolves than men who lie with silver tongues.”

Option.text: You truly are of the wild.
Even wolves seek packs. Don’t you?

Dialogue.NPCText:
“The spirits speak, if one listens. They are in the wind’s curve, the crack of old wood, the blood-music of a fresh kill. They do not demand temples, only reverence.”

“Minax’s blight tries to drown them in silence. That’s why we howl louder.”

Option.text: Have you ever heard them directly?

Dialogue.NPCText:
“You listen with more than your ears. That is rare.”
(Ejan draws a sigil in the air—leaves momentarily gather around you.)

Option.text: I want to hear more of your visions.

Dialogue.NPCText:
“In the last full moon, I dreamed of a tree with roots in fire and branches in stars. At its base, Minax clawed at the bark while wolves stood in silence, watching me.”

“The tree whispered: *‘Call the worthy, and feed the howl.’* I do not know what it means—yet.”

Option.text: I will help you understand it.

Dialogue.NPCText:
“I serve the Verdant not by command, but by root and oath. We are not an empire, not a nation. We are *balance*. Without us, the trees would scream and the spirits would wander lost.”

“I do not command the wild. I keep it from devouring itself.”

“Some burdens make us bow, others shape our backs into mountains. I have become both.”

“But sometimes I envy the fox—no duty but to hunt, to play, to curl into the wind and vanish.”

(Ejan’s expression hardens.)
“I howled when I was forbidden. I called a rain when drought was sacred. The council feared my power... or what I might awaken.”

“So yes, I was cast out. But the wild never turned me away. And now? The same council begs me to protect them from the shadows.”
(He smiles bitterly.)

“Trust is a rare flower—beautiful, but brittle. I trust the spirits. I trust the howl. As for the council?”
“Let their roots prove their worth, not their words.”
